Literary excellence.<[silence:1200]> Global recognition.<[silence:1200]>
The Nobel Prize in Literature awards authors for "outstanding work in an ideal direction," as defined by Alfred Nobel’s 1895 will.<[silence:1200]>

The prize began in 1901 after Nobel’s death, funded by his dynamite fortune.<[silence:1200]> The Swedish Academy selects winners via a multi-stage process: nominations from qualified experts, shortlisting by committee, and a final majority vote.<[silence:1200]> Unlike scientific Nobels, literature winners need no specific achievement—just a body of work shaping culture.<[silence:1200]>

Sully Prudhomme won first in 1901 for poetic idealism.<[silence:1200]> Later honorees include Toni Morrison (1993) for novels like *Beloved* exposing racial trauma, and Bob Dylan (2016) for lyrical poetry in songs like *Blowin’ in the Wind*.<[silence:1200]>

Controversies arise over political bias or overlooked genres.<[silence:1200]> Some winners, like Jean-Paul Sartre (1964), refuse the award.<[silence:1200]>
Postcolonial voices. Translated works. Experimental forms.<[silence:1200]>
